section.title: The process: XML
section.programlisting:
<definitions id="HelloWorld" targetNamespace="http://www.omg.org/bpmn20" xmlns="http://www.omg.org/spec/BPMN/20100524/MODEL">
<process id="helloWorld" name="Hello World"> <startEvent id="start" name="Start"> <outgoing>start2sayHello</outgoing> </startEvent> <userTask id="sayHello" name="Say Hello"> <incoming>start2sayHello</incoming> <outgoing>sayHello2end</outgoing> </userTask> <sequenceFlow id="start2sayHello" sourceRef="start" targetRef="sayHello"/> <endEvent id="end" name="End"> <incoming>sayHello2end</incoming> </endEvent> <sequenceFlow id="sayHello2end" sourceRef="sayHello" targetRef="end" /> </process>
</definitions>

callout.para: Any flow element, such as process, task, gateway may have both id and name attributes. The id attribute is used to uniquely identify elements. It is required if the element is to be referenced by another element. The name attribute serves as descriptive name of the element. When referencing BPMN elements from Work Token annotations id is preferred reference type, because it must be unique. However, not all BPMN diagram editors allow setting custom values for id attributes. Some editors may even regenerate ids on each update of the diagram. This is why Work Token annotations may use name attribute instead of id.
